Description: Body sherd of Corinthian black-figured pottery column-krater; interior glazed black; exterior: black-figure decoration consisting of two draped figures; from left, part of drapery of standing figure with added red remaining, to right; on right, standing figure (from below shoulders to knees; incised outline of lower part of right arm on black cloak with raised red dots; below, chiton in outline with wavy vertical fold lines), to right; painted inscriptions on exterior.
Curator's comments: C. W. Neeft (personal communication) considers that the sherd does not belong to a red ground vase, but rather the fabric was cleaned thoroughly prior to production of the vessel. The piece is more fully discussed by A. Johnston, 'Another two-and-a-half Corinthian dipinti', in Egraphsen kai Epoiesen (Essays on Greek pottery and iconography in honour of Professor Michalis Tiverios), Thessaloniki 2014, 120-2.
Bibliographic references: Vase / Catalogue of Vases in the British Museum (B102.29.1)
Payne 1931 / Necrocorinthia. A study of corinthian art in the archaic period (p.169, no. 71, note 2)
Venit 1982 / Painted Pottery from the Greek Mainland found in Egypt, 640-450 BC (p.110, no. A178)
Möller 2000 / Naukratis, Trade in Archaic Greece (p. 221, no.10)
Villing et al 2013-2015 / Naukratis: Greeks in Egypt (GB.060) (Phase 1)
